solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 1848\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{1848}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow Area of Base = \pi r^2 = \frac{1848}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {1848\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 14 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 7 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 4308.08 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 1848 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder in cubic centimetres

solution.text:
Curved Surface area of the roller \(= 2 \pi rh = 2 \times \frac {9}2 \times 14 = 395.64 cm^2\)
Area covered per rotation \(= 395.64 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area painted in 59 rolls \(= 395.64 \times l = 23342.76 cm^2\)

content.text: Last Monday, Ram painted a rectangular wall with a cylindrical paint roller. The length of the roller is 14 cm and its diameter is 9 cm. While painting, the roller rolled over 59 times completely. What surface area, in \(cm^2\), did Ram paint?

hint.text: How much area does the roller cover in one rotation?

solution.text:
Total surface area \(= 6 \times 15^2 = 6 (side)^2\)
\(=\Rightarrow Length of side = {\frac {1350}{6}}^{\frac 12} = 15 cm\)

content.text: A closed box in the shape of a cube has a total outer surface area of 1350 \(cm^2.\) What is the length of its side in centimetres?

hint.text: Remember that surface area of a cube is \(6 \times side^2\)

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 3787(21 \times 8) m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 21 \times 8 = 168 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 37870000

content.text: The area of your school library floor is \(636216 m^2\). You are asked to use tiles in the shape of a parallelogram with a base of 21 cm and a height of 8 cm to cover the floor. How many such tiles will you need to purchase? You can break the tiles in any way to cover the entire floor.

hint.text: Start by finding the area of each tile

solution.text:
Perimeter of cylinder = Breadth of paper
\(= 2\pi r = 14\)
Therefore, r = 2.23 cm
Volume of a cylinder \(= \pi r^2h = 390.13 cm^3\)

content.text: Rajiv likes to make 3D shapes from paper. Yesterday, he started with a rectangular piece of paper of length 25 cm and breadth 14 cm. He then rolled the paper into a cylinder so that the cylinder is now 25 cm long. What is the volume (in \(cm^3\)) of the air inside the cylinder so formed?

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 10^2 \times 48 = 15072 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = \pi \times 10^2 \times 48 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 29 \times 17 \times h = 15072 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {\pi \times 10^2 \times 48}{29 \times 17} = 30.57\)
The new cuboid is 30.57 cm tall

content.text: A metal cylinder of height 48 cm and radius 10 cm is melted and reshaped into a cuboid of length 29 cm and breadth 17 cm. No metal was wasted during this process. How tall is the new cuboid? (in cm)

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 126 \times 38\times \frac 12 \times 49\times((2 \times 126)-30)\)
\(= 26041932 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 5 km/hr = 5000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 26041932 \times (1000) \times 5) = 130209660000 m^3/hr\)
= 130209660000000 L/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7 \)hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 130209660000000\)
= 21875222880000000 litres

content.text: The Surya river is a small unknown river that flows into the Arabian Sea. The cross-section of the river can be approximated as the shape shown in the diagram below. You measure the dimensions of the river and find that a = 126 m, b = 96 m, c = 38 m and d= 87 m. The river flows at a constant rate of 5 km / hr. What volume of water (in litres) flows into the sea over the course of a week?

Therefore, the volume will double

Therefore, the volume will quadruple

V \(= \pi r^2h\)
\(V_ {new} = \pi (\frac r2)^2h = \frac V4\)
Therefore, the volume will quarter

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 15072 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be x
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (14)^2 \times 64 - \pi (14-x)^2 \times 64\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{64\pi}=14^2 - (14-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (14-x)^2 = 196 - \frac{V}{64\pi}
\(\Rightarrow x = 14 - 11\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

solution.text:
Total surface area of all the cubes \(= 5 \times 6 \times 1.4^2 = 58.8 cm^2\)
Area of each face =\(1.4^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 58.8 - 19.6 = 39.2 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 6 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(39.2 \times 6\)
= Rs.235.2

content.text: Five cubes of edge 1.4 cm each are placed side by side and stuck together as shown. The cost of painting is Rs 6 per \(cm^2\). What is the cost of painting the outer surface of the entire object? (in Rupees)

hint.text: Count the number of faces that are outward facing

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 154 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{154}{\pi} = 49.04 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 154 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 154 + 49.04\)
= 64.44 \(cm^2\)

content.text: You are given a cylindrical cake with icing on the top and bottom. There is no icing on the curved surface and the curved surface area is \(154 cm^2\). What surface area (in \(cm^2\)) of your slice has no icing?

Volume of pipe=Difference in volumes between outer and inner cylinder
\(= \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= \pi (22)^2 \times 73 - \pi18^2 \times 73\)
= 36675.2\( cm^3\)
Mass =\( Volume \times Density\)
\(\Rightarrow Mass = 36675.2 cm^3 \times \frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\)
= 315406.72 g

\(= 2 (7 \times 4 + 4 \times 4 + 7 \times 4) = 144 cm^2\)
Therefore, area of tin required for 14 boxes \(= 144 \times 14\)
\(= 2016 cm^2\)

content.text: You need to create a tin box of dimensions \(7 cm \times 4 cm \times 4 cm.\) What is the area, in square centimetres, of a sheet of tin required to make 14 such tins?

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \(\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= 9671.2 cm^3\)
Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h = \pi (\frac l2)^2 \times x - \pi (\frac l2 - 5)^2 \times x
=\( x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac l2)^2-\pi (\frac l2 - m)^2}\)
= 426.98 cm
Therefore, the length of the new tube is 426.98 cm

=\(\frac{sqrt{3}}{4}\times 1764 cm^2\)

Volume of water added = 114.58 L

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:
In the quadrilateral below, \(h1=8 cm\), \(h2=16 cm\), \(d=32 cm\)

solution.text:
Area of Quadrilateral = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Triangle (2)
\(= \frac 12 \times h1 \times d + \frac 12 \times h2 \times d\)
\(= (\frac 12 \times 8 \times 32) + (\frac 12 \times 16 \times 32)\)
=\(384 cm^2\)

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:
In the polygon below, a=32 cm, b=33 cm, c=33 cm, d=16 cm, e=9.6 cm, f=24 cm, g=32 cm

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 32 \times 33 + \frac 12 \times 42.6 \times 49 + \frac 12 \times 9.6 \times 24 + \frac \times 32 \times 25.6 + \frac \times 65 \times 32\)
\(=3136.5 cm^2\)

content.text: The unit in which the answer will be:

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Trapezium (1) + Area of Trapezium (2)
= Area of Trapezium \(\times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (a+c)(h) \times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (16.5 + 44)(11) \times 2\)
\(= 665.5 mm^2\)

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\times\pi \times 21 \times 10 + 2 \pi \times 5 \times 10 + 2(\pi \times 21^2 - \pi \times 5^2)\)
= 4245.28\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 4245.28 \times 0.2\)
= Rs.849.056

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 21 cm and an inner diameter of 5 cm. Its length is 10 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 1664 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid? (in metres)
What is the Breadth of the cuboid? (in metres)

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \1664 m^2\)
Therefore, \(1664 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{1664}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{16}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 4 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid? (in metres)

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)
